habitat_description:
Killdeer can be found throughout the U.S. in wet or dry open habitats with little, short, or no vegetative cover, including sandbars, gravel bars, mudflats, heavily grazed pastures, short-grass prairies and meadows (usually, but not always, with vegetation <1 cm tall), cultivated fields, athletic fields, construction sites, road shoulders, gravel roads and driveways, lawns, airports, golf courses, graveled or broken-asphalt parking lots, and graveled rooftops (Jackson and Jackson 2000).  Although they often live far from water bodies, they are usually found near a water source of some sort.  In Arizona, the species is reportedly associated with permanent water.  Nests are composed of a shallow scrape in an area with none or little vegetation, frequently but not always on a small raised area (Jackson and Jackson 2000). 

Killdeers are abundant in the Southwest where they can be found year-round along rivers, lakes, and around small waterholes or even sometimes where water is practically non-existent.   Most move out of northern Nevada in mid-winter.

Winter habitat associations are similar to those of summer. N. Tarr, 7July2011.
